text:
As Carolyn said, SEOs use tools, HOWEVER many writers don’t … they’re Googling search terms to pull up “people also search for” so that will account for some of the volume. 

It’s like gated content … how many of those “leads” are really just writers doing research?

text:
*Set goals for content distribution  in Q4*

Hey folks, I am in the process of defining the goals for the next quarter. I would like to include the distribution (organic social media and newsletter) of our content from our magazine in the OKR to give this more importance.

_Background info:_
We’re a company who work in the travel industry (camper rental). In Q4 there’s not much going on and people don't really search for camping content in winter so we’re trying to recycle our content and focus on distribution to get traffic.

I was thinking about tracking the referral traffic which come from the organic social media posts and our 1 newsletter we send out every two weeks.

• do you think that make sense? Or do you have other suggestions / thoughts about this?
• do I need to track something else than the referral traffic or additional KPIs?
• and how much growth should be possible for a one-person-team? (e.g. +20% referral traffic?)
I’m really looking forward reading your thoughts about this. :)

elements.text: Set goals for content distribution  in Q4

Hey folks, I am in the process of defining the goals for the next quarter. I would like to include the distribution (organic social media and newsletter) of our content from our magazine in the OKR to give this more importance.
Background info:

We’re a company who work in the travel industry (camper rental). In Q4 there’s not much going on and people don't really search for camping content in winter so we’re trying to recycle our content and focus on distribution to get traffic.

I was thinking about tracking the referral traffic which come from the organic social media posts and our 1 newsletter we send out every two weeks.
do you think that make sense? Or do you have other suggestions / thoughts about this?
do I need to track something else than the referral traffic or additional KPIs?
and how much growth should be possible for a one-person-team? (e.g. +20% referral traffic?)
I’m really looking forward reading your thoughts about this. :)

text:
When does the sales/value activity ramp back up? Part of the downtime goal could be to ensure your brand is top of mind come "sales season."

Framed that way, traffic _growth_ may not the end-all-be-all goal. Maybe you're trying to keep traffic/engagement at or above an industry standard. Or keep it at or above last Q4's traffic. Or rank well (vs grow traffic for) for content that speaks aspirationally towards the spring (or whenever sales ramps again).

Traffic growth to demonstrate the success of more distribution focus is still a decent thing to do though. "numbers go up" is a simple story for execs to buy into. But it can also be a huge trap. There is no standard growth rate target for a one person team, it all depends on context. So it's often wise to have other ways to measure success that tie back to the story / goals of the bigger business.

text:
Ah. See, I don't think tossing a style guide over the fence will fix much (aka bad time continues). If these folks are all strategically challenged as you say, even if the style guide is one thing, 15 different people will interpret it 15 different ways.

A mixed approach might work better, depending on how much bandwidth you have. Design a blog writing template using the style guide, and ask the folks to use said template. It'll still be a bit of a mishmash, but hopefully the depth, breadth and maybe even tone will converge slightly. But your editing team (aka, you) will still need to rework the input into a singular voice, without relying on the 15 entities to go through N rounds of revision.

If that sounds like bottleneck hell, you may need to bring on an editor to alleviate. As for justifying the cost, compare time saved chasing 15 people and negotiating edits.

Ideally:

• Template + brief goes out
• 15 folks submit round 1, template helps manage some convergence in style
• Editing team (hopefully more than just you?) reworks towards desired convergence
• Publish
If the contributors can't handle the deviance from what they originally submitted... well, I think that's a different problem altogether (could involve a contract renegotiation or something? Tis more of a higher order issue compared to an editing one) ~ <@U015BEETZ2P>

A mixed approach might work better, depending on how much bandwidth you have. Design a blog writing template using the style guide, and ask the folks to use said template. It'll still be a bit of a mishmash, but hopefully the depth, breadth and maybe even tone will converge slightly. But your editing team (aka, you) will still need to rework the input into a singular voice, without relying on the 15 entities to go through N rounds of revision.

If that sounds like bottleneck hell, you may need to bring on an editor to alleviate. As for justifying the cost, compare time saved chasing 15 people and negotiating edits.

Ideally:
Template + brief goes out
15 folks submit round 1, template helps manage some convergence in style
Editing team (hopefully more than just you?) reworks towards desired convergence
Publish

If the contributors can't handle the deviance from what they originally submitted... well, I think that's a different problem altogether (could involve a contract renegotiation or something? Tis more of a higher order issue compared to an editing one) ~

text:
Does anyone else here work in an organization with two (or more) teams heavily contributing to your blog and overall content?

Specifically, I would love to talk to anyone that has a separate SEO content team, and another content team, that work in tandem. I’m curious about each of the team’s goals, how you collaborate and where your efforts work together and differ. Also happy to DM about this if you’re in a similar boat!

text:
Does anyone have a process for content distribution and repurposing across different channels that's worked well for them?

I work with an _editorial board_ team that includes the owners of different marketing channels (e.g. social, email, etc) as well as other content stakeholders that distribute content (e.g. brand partnerships, retail, etc.). We're trying to establish a workflow for content promotion/distribution (in line with the content hub editorial calendar which is the channle I own) to maximize the impact of our content and find opportunities for repurposing for different channels. 

Any tips on how to best integrate content distribution within the content production workflow?

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

For those of you who work in health, beauty, or wellness, do you have your content reviewed by medical professionals? If so, how do you go about finding those experts who can review your content to ensure it's medically accurate?

text:
A few years ago, I worked as an in-house content strategist & writer for a Peruvian company that has a few health & wellness domains. If I’m not mistaken, the company found  their medical professionals simply by posting on a local job board. After interviewing them to make sure they had the right credentials, those medical professionals then came into the office a couple times a week to review everything we wrote. 

So, I’d say try the same, <@U022WPACV4L>. Or reach out to your network to see who pops up.
